title: Senate Dems raise concerns about ISIS strategy after closed-door briefing
text:
ADVERTISEMENT

Senate Democrats emerged from a closed-door briefing Wednesday saying they need more details about the administration's strategy to counter ISIS in the wake of the U.S. pullback in northern Syria.Senators were briefed about the raid that led to the death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of ISIS, and broader Syra strategy.Senate Minority Leader(D-N.Y.) called the military mission "incredible" but that "it is clear ISIS continues.""They are not vanquished, they are not over. ...I believe that the Administration has to do more to make sure the existing ISIS prisoners are guarded, to track down those who have escaped, and to have a far more concrete plan on how we deal with ISIS in the future," Schumer told reporters.Schumer's concerns were echoed by several Democrats who attended the briefing, which marked the first all-members meeting the Senate has had since the White House announced they were pulling back troops from northern Syria."I am more concerned than ever, deeply alarmed, about the threat of ISIS," Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) told reporters.He added that Baghdadi's death has helped weaken ISIS, but "the resurgence of ISIS is more alarming than ever."Sen.(D-Ill.), Schumer's No. 2, added that countering ISIS "still is our stated objective" within Syria, "but the means of achieving it are not as clear as they were before the president's phone call with Erdogan."
description: Senate Democrats emerged from a closed-door briefing Wednesday saying they need more details about the administration's strategy to counter ISIS in the wake of the U.S. pullback in northern Syria.
